awd_titl_txt: Planning: Montana NSF ESPCoR RII Track-1 23-28 Planning Grant
awd_abstract_narration:
This planning proposal, submitted by Montana State University (MSU), requests support for team development and planning activities that will analyze statewide capacity and infrastructure, develop a framework for the research topic, identify workforce
development opportunities and develop project sustainability. Planning activities will involve participation of statewide teams representing the Montana University System and will include coordination with the jurisdictional EPSCoR Steering Committee and the Office for the Commissioner of Higher Education. These planning activities will develop the foundation for an RII Track-1 proposal and project that will advance research capacity and workforce development in areas that are important to the state of Montana and promote education, inclusion, and diversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
These planning activities developed a team and foundation for an RII Track-1 proposal and project that will advance research capacity and workforce development in areas that are important to the state of Montana and promote statewide education, inclusion, and diversity. The planning efforts undertaken will help ensure that a future RII Track-1 project will maximize impact, build capacity, mitigate risks, and ensure long-lasting sustainability.

The theme of the proposal itself will focus on the science and impact of prescribed fire, a strategy employed to reduce the risk and severity of wildfires.  This theme is particularly pressing in the Western US, and the Montana jurisdiction has the expertise across its university system to address questions such as "Where to burn?  When to burn? and For how long to burn?".  An important aspect of the project will consider the public perception and impact of prescribed fire in Montana's communities.  The proposal will also draw from historical knowledge and practices employed by Indigenous peoples across the state and liaise with tribal communities with colleagues at two tribal colleges initially with the intent to expand to more tribal colleges as the project matures.

This planning grant proposal supported team development and planning activities that analyzed statewide capacity and infrastructure, developed a framework for a new research topic, and identified workforce development and project sustainability needs and opportunities.

Planning activities involved participation of statewide teams representing the Montana University System and two tribal colleges, and included coordination with the jurisdictional EPSCoR Steering Committee and the Office for the Commissioner of Higher Education.
